Article.Abstract: Using a murine model, we investigated the role of the bacterial exotoxin listeriolysin O (LLO) in cellular immunity to Listeria monocytogenes. A correlation between LLO production by infecting bacteria and generation of protective immunity to virulent LLO-producing bacteria was noted. Using isogeneic hemolysin (Hly+ or Hly-) strains of L. monocytogenes, we demonstrated that LLO production by infecting bacteria is required to elicit T cells reactive both to bacteria-associated Ag and to the secreted LLO molecule as measured by IL-2 production in vitro. Distinct sets of T cells specific for largely nonoverlapping pools of antigenic determinants represented by LLO and cell-associated Ag (heat-killed L. monocytogenes) are generated after infection. We have used models for prediction of T cell epitopes based on primary structure of LLO, and synthetic amphipathic LLO peptides were evaluated as Ag in vitro or as immunogenes in vivo. Infection of several strains of mice (H-2k and H-2d) with LLO-producing L. monocytogenes resulted in the generation of T cells that could respond consistently to two peptides, LLO 215-234 and LLO 354-371. Mouse strains lacking expression of I-E molecules (e.g., B10.A(4R) and C57BL/6) responded to LLO but not to the peptides tested. With C3HeB/FeJ mice, antibodies to I-Ek blocked the presentation of LLO 215-234. The importance of the N-terminal portion of LLO 215-234 was evidenced by the drastic reduction in antigenic activity of truncated peptides (e.g., LLO 221-234 and LLO 224-234). LLO 215-234, the strongest and most consistent activator of T cells from L. monocytogenes-immune mice, fit well some models for antigenic peptides in several ways. It could be predicted to form an amphipathic alpha-helix, it contained multiple "Rothbard motifs" (charged residue or glycine, two or three hydrophobic amino acids and then a glycine or polar residue), it had a net charge of +2, and it contained the correct spacing of amino acids (five to six residues between a hydrophobic and basic amino acid) that is characteristic of I-Ek-binding peptides. Immunization with 8 of 10 synthetic LLO peptides generated T cells that recognized the immunizing peptide in vitro, but such T cells were only poorly reactive with LLO. Our results indicate that LLO is an important target Ag for stimulation of CD4+ L. monocytogenes-specific T cells, and that LLO 215-234 is antigenically dominant in C3HeB/FeJ mice.
Article.ArticleTitle: Role of listeriolysin-O (LLO) in the T lymphocyte response to infection with Listeria monocytogenes. Identification of T cell epitopes of LLO.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Microbiology and Immunology, Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, GA 30322.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antibodies, Monoclonal;Antigens, Bacterial;Bacterial Toxins;Bacterial Vaccines;Epitopes;Heat-Shock Proteins;Hemolysin Proteins;Histocompatibility Antigens Class II;hlyA protein, Listeria monocytogenes
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Animals; Antibodies, Monoclonal(immunology); Antigens, Bacterial(immunology); Bacterial Toxins; Bacterial Vaccines(immunology); Epitopes(analysis); Heat-Shock Proteins(immunology; physiology); Hemolysin Proteins; Histocompatibility Antigens Class II(immunology); Immunization; Listeria monocytogenes(immunology); Listeriosis(prevention & control); Mice; Mice, Inbred Strains; Protein Conformation; T-Lymphocytes(immunology)

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were injected on four sites on the back near each limb, and secondary injections 1 month later. One week later, they were injected with 10% proteose peptone and sacrificed 3 days later.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IL-2 production was determined based on the proliferative response of IL-2-responsive HT-2 cells. Effector cells and macrophages were taken from peritoneal exudate cells. C3HeB/FeJ mice were used for 1 of 3 experiments. The authors reported occasional, but inconsistent cross-reactivity with other Lysteriolysin peptides studied.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were injected on four sites on the back near each limb, and secondary injections 1 month later. One week later, they were injected with 10% proteose peptone and sacrificed 3 days later.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized with Hemolysin + Lysteria monocytogenes.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IL-2 production was determined based on the proliferative response of IL-2-responsive HT-2 cells. Effector cells and macrophages were taken from peritoneal exudate cells. T cells from mice immunized with epitope, or a mix of the other ten peptides studied, were more strongly reactive to the immunizing peptides than to the native Lysteriolysin molecule.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were given primary immunizations with live Lysteria monocytogenes and secondary immunizations with live Lysteria monocytogenes two weeks later. Mice were sacrificed 3 days later.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were injected with the Hemolysin + strain of Lysteria monocytogenes.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IL-2 production was determined based on the proliferative response of IL-2-responsive HT-2 cells. Effector cells and macrophages were taken from peritoneal exudate cells. A similar response was shown in B10.S (12R), B10.PL, and B10.A (4R) mice.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were sacrificed 8 days after primary injection, and peritoneal exudate cells were collected.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were injected with both Hemolysin + and Heolysin - strains of Lysteria monocytogenes.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IL-2 production was determined based on the proliferative response of IL-2-responsive HT-2 cells. Effector cells were taken from peritoneal exudate cells. Small numbers of Hemolysin + bacteria elicited T cell responses, while large numbers of Hemolysin - bacteria did not.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were given primary immunizations with live Lysteria monocytogenes and secondary immunizations with live Lysteria monocytogenes two weeks later. Mice were sacrificed 3 days later.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were injected with the Hemolysin + strain of Lysteria monocytogenes.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IL-2 production was determined based on the proliferative response of IL-2-responsive HT-2 cells. Effector cells and macrophages were taken from peritoneal exudate cells. Two of the six experiments utilized nylon wool purified T cells from immunnized mice, while the rest used nonadherent lymphocytes. All amino-terminus epitope truncations were shown to significantly decreased antigenic activity. A similar response was shown in BALB/c and (C3H x DBA/2) F1 mice. Responses were inhibited significantly with antibodies to both I-E<sup>k</sup> and I-A<sup>k</sup>, but not by antibodies to I-A<sup>d</sup>.
